title: Trade&Development in Practice
description: This course provides a practical and critical perspective on major contemporary economic debates that pertain to international trade and development. Since the 2008-09 crisis, the trade and development paradigms have changed: with the emergence of global value chains, more countries can participate to global production and trade, but the elasticity and volatility of trade flows have increased; with the emergence of China and other developing countries, demand and supply started to shift to the South, raising questions about outsourcing/offshoring, protectionism and national preferences. In this course, we question the evolution of the world trading system from a development perspective. A particular attention is paid to the “trade and…” issues: Is trade in services only in the interest of rich countries? Are trade rules a threat to public health and access to medicines in the poorest countries? Is trade part of the problem or the solution to climate change? How does trade affect food security and commodity prices fluctuations? Is currency under-evaluation a form of unfair competition? Is the cross-border movement of workers a source of brain drain or brain gain? Are high labor and environmental standards a form of diktat from the North? At the end of the course, students should be able to challenge most preconceived ideas about trade and development that flourish in the media and elsewhere.
